abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory,
            while project sustainability is likely. The overall
            performances of both the World Bank and the Borrower were
            adjudged satisfactory. These are some of the lessons
            learned: 1) During project formulation, there was a serious
            debate about the structure of the credit. With the evolution
            of the political structure of the FRY, it was not clear what
            role the Federal Government or the Republic of Serbia would
            play. Because nearly all of the reforms were to be
            implemented by the Republic of Serbia, it was decided to
            target the Credit to the Republic of Serbia, with FRY
            primarily playing the role of a borrower which would pass
            through the counterpart funds to the Republic of Serbia.
            Thus, the role of the FRY was, owing to the institutional
            structure, minimal. In general, the Bank should engage the
            level of government which will be in charge of formulating
            and implementing reforms, and, if for legal reasons, another
            level of government needs to be involved in borrowing, this
            role should be kept to the minimum necessary to convey
            funding to the operationally relevant level of government.
            This, especially in cases where the "central"
            government is withdrawing from managing the constituent
            republics.  2) Coherence and credibility are important for
            adjustment operations. While this is true for all adjustment
            operations, it is especially true for operations such as
            this SAC which help initiate adjustment lending to a country
            where the political landscape itself is changing with
            evolving governmental relationships and a new public
            attitude towards economic reform. Combining a few important
            fiscal issues with a broader institutional reform program
            lends coherence and credibility to such an adjustment
            operation. The fiscal and quasi-fiscal impact of the SAC
            were essential for its adjustment focus, while, at the same
            time, the new Serbian Government benefited from the detailed
            program for the sectors. 3) Reform implementation is heavily
            dependent on an effective champion. In both the energy and
            health sectors, SAC reforms were delayed because of
            ministerial changes, and only when the new ministers were
            appointed could the program proceed. 4) The Country Economic
            Memorandum, "Breaking with the Past" helped
            government to focus on key reforms, and enabled government
            and the Bank to work together on defining sectors to be
            included in the SAC, and the key issues which needed to be
            addressed in those sectors.
